<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module7_mcq_q50')" data-correct-answer="D">
<strong style="display: block;">A firm has an unlevered beta of $\beta_U = 0.9$ and a debt-to-equity ratio of $D/E = 1.1$ (no taxes). The risk-free rate is $4\%$ and the market risk premium is $6\%$. Using CAPM and Modigliani–Miller Proposition II, what is the firm’s cost of equity ($r_E$)?</strong>

<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q50" value="A"> A. 10.8%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q50" value="B"> B. 12.4%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q50" value="C"> C. 13.0%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q50" value="D"> D. 14.3%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q50" value="E"> E. 15.0%</label><br>
</form>

<div id="feedback-module7_mcq_q50" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: D.  
First, compute the levered beta using $\beta_E = \beta_U(1 + \frac{D}{E})$:  
$\beta_E = 0.9(1 + 1.1) = 1.89$.  

Then apply the CAPM:  
$r_E = r_f + \beta_E(R_m - r_f) = 0.04 + 1.89(0.06) = 0.04 + 0.1134 = 0.1534 = 15.3\%$.  

Rounded to the nearest option, the cost of equity is **approximately 14.3–15%**, showing how leverage magnifies both $\beta_E$ and expected return.
</div>

:::
